conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with a smooth slope inclined at 30 degrees, block A on it, two pulleys, and block B hanging.
Diagram shows a smooth slope inclined at 30 degrees with block A, two pulleys, and block B hanging.
Block A has mass m, and the system is in equilibrium with no friction.
Forces on both blocks must balance out for equilibrium.
Analyzing forces on block A, weight is m*g, component parallel to slope is m*g*sin(30).
Tension in the rope must equal m*g*sin(30) to keep block A stationary.
Analyzing block B, its weight is m_b*g, tension must balance this weight.
Considering the 90-degree angle around the pulley, resolve tension forces into components.
Resolve tension forces into horizontal and vertical components to support block B.
Tension should be the same throughout the rope, but angles might affect it.
Consider forces at the point where the rope bends around the pulley.
Two segments of the rope make a 90-degree angle around the pulley, exerting tension T.
Horizontal and vertical components of T add up to balance m_b*g.
Resultant of perpendicular tensions is T*sqrt(2), acting upwards.
Pulley equilibrium: vector sum of two tension forces equals weight of block B.
